Candidatus Fukatsuia endosymbiont of Tuberolachnus salignus is a bacterial endosymbiont that resides within the body of the willow aphid, Tuberolachnus salignus. This species of bacteria is classified as a "Candidatus" designation, which indicates that it has not been formally described and named according to the rules of bacterial taxonomy, but its existence and characteristics have been identified through genomic and microscopic analyses.

The Candidatus Fukatsuia endosymbiont is believed to have a mutualistic relationship with its host, the willow aphid. It is thought to provide essential nutrients or other metabolic functions that contribute to the aphid's survival and reproduction. The endosymbiont is vertically transmitted, meaning it is passed from one generation of aphids to the next, ensuring its continuous presence within the host population.

Genomic studies have revealed that the Candidatus Fukatsuia endosymbiont has a reduced genome size compared to free-living bacteria, which is a common characteristic of obligate endosymbionts that rely on their host for many essential functions. This symbiotic relationship between the bacteria and the willow aphid is an example of the complex and intricate interactions that can evolve between insects and their microbial associates.
